sub_topic: Logistic growth models for population growth
message_1: A certain population initially consists of 500 individuals and the carrying capacity of their habitat is 10,000 individuals. The annual growth rate is 20%. Using the logistic growth model, determine the size of the population after 3 years.
message_2:
The logistic growth model is given by the equation:

P(t) = K / (1 + (K - P₀) / P₀ * e^(-r * t))

where:
P(t) is the population size at time t,
P₀ is the initial population size,
K is the carrying capacity,
r is the annual growth rate, and
t is the time in years.

In this problem, we have:
P₀ = 500 (initial population),
K = 10,000 (carrying capacity),
r = 0.20 (annual growth rate), and
t = 3 (years).

We want to find P(3), the population size after 3 years. Plugging the values into the logistic growth model equation, we get:

P(3) = 10,000 / (1 + (10,000 - 500) / 500 * e^(-0.20 * 3))

P(3) = 10,000 / (1 + 9500 / 500 * e^(-0.60))

P(3) = 10,000 / (1 + 19 * e^(-0.60))

Now, we calculate the value of e^(-0.60):

e^(-0.60) ≈ 0.5488

Now, we plug this value back into the equation:

P(3) = 10,000 / (1 + 19 * 0.5488)

P(3) = 10,000 / (1 + 10.4262)

P(3) = 10,000 / 11.4262

Finally, we calculate the population size after 3 years:

P(3) ≈ 874.64

Since we cannot have a fraction of an individual, we can round this value to the nearest whole number. Therefore, the population size after 3 years will be approximately 875 individuals.
